'''Henri Joseph Stahl''' (also known as '''Henric''', '''Enric''', or '''Henry Stahl'''; April 29, 1877 – February 18, 1942) was a [[Romania]]n [[Stenography|stenographer]], [[Graphology|graphologist]], historian and fiction writer. Born to educated immigrant parents, he was a friend and disciple of [[Nicolae Iorga]], doyen of modern Romanian historiography. Much of his work in the field resulted in a monographic and [[Conservation (cultural heritage)|conservationist]] study of his native [[Bucharest]], which was published by Iorga in 1910.
Stahl created an original system of a stenography, which worked as one of the basic Romanian stenography standards, and, as resident expert at the [[National Archives of Romania|National Archives]], set up the Romanian school of graphology and [[paleography]]. The author of humorous stories and memoirs, he also contributed the novel ''Un român în lună'' ("A Romanian on the Moon"), seen as one of the pioneering works in [[Romanian science fiction]].
In addition to his scholarly and literary work, Stahl worked as a stenographer for public institutions, which allowed him to witness significant events in Romanian political history, and was a distinguished veteran of World War I. Stahl was the father of sociologist [[Henri H. Stahl]] and of novelist [[Henriette Yvonne Stahl]], as well as the stepfather of [[Șerban Voinea]], a political thinker and militant of the [[Romanian Social Democratic Party (1927-1948)|Romanian Social Democratic Party]].
==Biography==
===Origins and early life=== Henri Stahl was the son of an [[Oriental studies|Orientalist]] and lexicographer, Joseph "Iosif" Stahl (1820–1890), described in sources as "a cross between an [[Alsace|Alsatian]] man and a Swiss woman",<ref name="mi40">Ioanid, p. 40</ref> or, in the Stahls' genealogy, as a [[Bavarians|Bavarian]] baron.<ref>Bălaj, p. 24. See also Mihăilescu, pp. 36–37</ref> According to Henriette Yvonne Stahl, her grandfather was originally active in the [[Kingdom of Greece]], in service to [[Otto of Greece|King Otto]], before being taken prisoner by the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref name="l-lb24">Bălaj, p. 24</ref> He owed his relocation to [[Wallachia]] (an autonomous subject of the Ottomans) to the intercession of [[List of rulers of Wallachia|Prince]] [[Barbu Dimitrie Știrbei]], who employed him as a ''[[Dragoman]]'' of the court.<ref>Bălaj, p. 24; Ioanid, p. 40</ref> Reportedly, his second wife, Irma Niard, known in Romanian as ''Irina Stahl'',<ref>''Anuarul Bucurescilor'', p. 149</ref> was from a [[Normandy|Normand]] family, the orphaned daughter of a prize-winning painter.<ref name="l-lb24"/> From Joseph's earlier marriage, Henri had a half-sister, Ana "Nety" Stahl (1853–1929).<ref>Bălaj, pp. 24–25</ref>
The Stahls lived in Wallachia, and later in [[United Principalities|unified Romania]], as pedagogues and owners of a boarding school (although Irma never learned Romanian).<ref name="l-lb24"/> By the time of Henri's birth, Joseph had had a lengthy career in publishing, with phrasebooks for German, French or Romanian, beginning with the 1853 ''Kleine Walachische Sprachlehre''.<ref>Angheluță ''et al.'', pp. 336–337, 810. See also Bălaj, pp. 24–25; Ioanid, p. 40; Stahl, p. 14</ref>
Born in Bucharest, Henri was himself a polyglot and a student of history. He enlisted at the [[University of Bucharest|city's university]], where he became one of Iorga's star students and fervent followers.<ref>Stahl, p. 14</ref> According to sociologist Mircea Ioanid, "he made himself famous with his modest but fruitful activities in the public sphere, but most of all though his cultural pioneering".<ref name="mi40"/> A graduate of the Faculty of Letters, Stahl invented a method for Romanian stenography, which was based on [[Duployan shorthand]].<ref name="la&al335">Angheluță ''et al.'', p. 335</ref> He outlined its rules in a 1900 textbook: ''Metoda pentru a stenografia cu alfabetul latin pentru uzul studenților, ziariștilor și tuturor celor care au de scris repede'' ("A Method for Stenography in the Latin Alphabet, Useful to Students, Journalists and All Those Who Have to Write Fast").<ref name="la&alxv335">Angheluță ''et al.'', pp. XV, 335</ref> By then, Stahl had been employed as a reviewer-stenographer by the [[Parliament of Romania]].<ref name="la&al335"/>
Around 1900, Stahl was in France, where he published a guide to the Duployan method and a [[stenotype]] how-to: ''La machine à écrire—machine à stenographier''.<ref name="la&al335"/> He fell deeply in love with a Blanche-Alexandrine Francis Boeuve, who taught at her mother's school in Bucharest. She was three years his senior,<ref name="l-lb25">Bălaj, p. 25</ref> had worked as a seamstress,<ref name="arhexil">{{ro icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20160303212949/http://www.arhivaexilului.ro/ro/fise-biografice/docs/voinea-serban.html "Voinea Șerban"], entry in ''Geografia exilului românesc'', [[Institute for the Investigation of Communist Crimes and Memory of the Romanian Exile]]; retrieved July 12, 2014</ref> and had [[History of the Jews in France|French Jewish]] origins.<ref name="anro&evr">{{ro icon}} Adrian Niculescu, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Romani-si-evrei-in-exilul-romanesc*articleID_4819-articles_details.html "Români și evrei în exilul românesc"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 133, September 2002</ref> From a previous relationship, Blanche had a six-year-old son, Gaston.<ref name="l-lb25"/><ref name="arhexil"/>
The affair angered Irma Stahl, who sacked Blanche after she let known that she carried Stahl's child.<ref name="l-lb25"/> Moving in with her sister in [[Saint-Avold]], [[Lorraine (region)|Lorraine]], she gave birth to a daughter, Henriette. The forceful separation and Henriette's health problems as an infant led Stahl to contemplate suicide; Irma Stahl eventually yielded to his threats, allowing mother and daughter to return and live with her in Bucharest.<ref>Bălaj, pp. 25–26</ref>
Henri legally married Blanche in 1901.<ref name="arhexil"/> The couple soon had another son, Henri H. Stahl. Blanche became an expert in [[touch typing]], and, after her move to Romania, wrote several textbooks of her own.<ref name="la&alxv335"/> By then, Henri was experimenting with political and humorous writing. In 1901, he became a contributor to [[Ion Luca Caragiale]]'s satirical sheet, ''[[Moftul Român]]''.<ref>Iorga, p. 30</ref> He was an imitator of Caragiale, and, according to Iorga, was one of the best, fitted with a "tender understanding of things".<ref>Iorga, pp. 183–184</ref> Having acquired a first-hand understanding of the emerging Romanian trends in public speaking, Stahl also published a September 1906 notice on the "style of Romanian orators" in the [[Blaj]] review ''Revista Politică și Literară''.<ref>Ileana Ghemeș, "Aplicări ale direcțiunii naționale în ''Revista Politică și Literară'' de la Blaj, în 1906", in ''Annales Universitatis Apulensis. Series Philologica'', Vol. 6, 2005, pp. 45–48</ref>
===Oral historian and science fiction author=== In 1903, Stahl was working for the Chancellery of the [[Senate of Romania|Romanian Senate]] and was teacher at his mother and wife's boarding school on Brutus Street (where he also resided).<ref>''Anuarul Bucurescilor'', pp. 6, 149, 228, 359, 410</ref> Stahl resumed his close contacts with Iorga: Iorga regularly visited Stahl's home and office, where he freely dictated his books for Stahl to write down.<ref>Ioanid, p. 40; Stahl, p. 14</ref> Stahl also joined the staff of Iorga's summer school in [[Vălenii de Munte]], where, in 1908, he was teaching stenography courses.<ref>{{ro icon}} Cătălin Fudulu, [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/dosare-declasificate-nicolae-iorga-sub-lupa-sigurantei-ii-4904721/ "Dosare declasificate. Nicolae Iorga sub lupa Siguranței (II)"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', September 16, 2009</ref> Iorga's academic press of Vălenii put out his 1909 ''Curs complect de stenografie cu vocale'' ("Complete Course of Stenography, Vowels Included").<ref name="la&alxv335"/> Also that year, he put out a French-language introduction to French and German stenography, [[Lithography|lithographed]] in Bucharest.<ref name="la&al335"/>
In addition to such contributions, Stahl preserved a passion for [[oral history]] and the [[history of Bucharest]]. He walked through the city, made notes of its interesting features, created [[Stone rubbing|stone rubs]] from old inscriptions, and interviewed senior citizens.<ref>Stahl, pp. 16–17</ref> His son Henri Jr, who followed him on such excursions, recalls: "He had the special gift of being able to converse with simple people, old and young alike, winning them over with his own matching simplicity, addressing them in their own language, in the very spirit of their mentality."<ref>Stahl, p. 16</ref> As literary critic [[Dan C. Mihăilescu]] notes, Stahl and Iorga were both conservative adversaries of 20th-century modernization, who disliked popular culture and feared the growth of the ''[[petite bourgeoisie]]''.<ref name="dcmrău">{{ro icon}} [[Dan C. Mihăilescu]], [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/rau-de-bucuresti-2985587/ "Rău de București"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', March 19, 2003</ref> Henri Jr also sees his father as a disciple of Iorga's traditionalist doctrine, or ''[[Sămănătorul|Sămănătorism]]''.<ref>Stahl, pp. 15, 16, 17</ref>
Occasionally, Stahl returned to fiction writing, producing ''Un român în lună'', the [[found manuscript]] of space exploration: a newspaperman chances upon a mysterious text, which turns out to be the stenographic account of a Romanian voyage to the Moon.<ref>Popescu, pp. 33, 34, 38–39</ref> Stahl described his novel as more of a "popular treatise in astronomy", a "well-written" and accessible illustration of scientific facts.<ref>Popescu, pp. 34–35</ref> In his 1915 review of the novel, [[Mihail Sevastos]] of ''[[Viața Românească]]'' noted: "Mr. Stahl imagined himself a [[Camille Flammarion|Flammarion]] of the Romanians".<ref name="rd.s303">[[Mihail Sevastos|Rd. S.]], p. 303</ref> According to philologist Petru Iamandi, the book's "rather obvious [[positivism]]" is balanced by "enthusiasm" and "funny remarks", but "the lack of a genuine conflict [is] the main shortcoming of Stahl's book".<ref>Petru Iamandi, "Romanian SF in the Latter Half of the 19th Century and the First Half of the 20th Century", in ''Analele Universității Dunărea de Jos din Galați'', Nr. 1-1/2013 (''Actele Conferinței Internaționale Lexic Comun – Lexic Specializat''), p. 224</ref> As noted in 1998 by cultural journalist [[Cristian Tudor Popescu]], ''Un român în lună'' can indeed be considered important for the emergence of [[Romanian science fiction]], but it is also "negligent" and "inferior" to its Western models, from [[Edgar Allan Poe]] to [[Jules Verne]].<ref>Popescu, pp. 33–34</ref> The unique element, Popescu suggests, is the explorer's motivation: he has left Earth out of [[misanthropy]] and disgust for politicking, but also for a belief in human transcendence (an "[[Omega Point]]", according to Popescu).<ref>Popescu, pp. 36–37, 39–41</ref> Sevastos pointed out that Stahl's "social criticism" was of the "aggressive" kind, quoting a passage in which the narrator reads Iorga's initials, "dear as they will once be to all Romanians", into the lunar surface.<ref name="rd.s303"/>
Stahl considered publishing the work, and showed it to Iorga for a critical opinion. He met Iorga's opposition, who asked him "to forget the moon and stars" and write a new book using the style around the first chapter, in which Stahl depicts life in turn-of-the-century Bucharest.<ref>Manolescu, pp. 231–233</ref> Therefore, Stahl's literary debut was in 1910 with ''Bucureștii ce se duc'' ("Vanishing Bucharest"), serialized in Iorga's ''[[Neamul Românesc]]'' journal,<ref name="dcmrău"/> then bound together as a volume issued in Vălenii.<ref>Angheluță ''et al.'', p. 335; Țurlea, p. 67</ref> Iorga later described Stahl, alongside [[Ion Agârbiceanu]], [[Romulus Cioflec]] and [[Dumitru C. Moruzi]], as ''Neamul Românesc''{{'}}s leading prose writer.<ref>Iorga, p. 209</ref>
The book is feted for its colorful depictions of Bucharesters at the beginning of the 20th century,<ref>{{ro icon}} Simona Câlția, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/ISTORIE.-Henri-STAHL-Bucurestii-ce-se-duc*articleID_8310-articles_details.html "Henri Stahl, ''Bucureştii ce se duc''"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 171, May–June 2003</ref> but also for outlining the conservative thesis favored at ''Neamul Românesc''. Stahl sees modern Bucharest as a playing ground for handmaidens and their aroused admirers, riddled with "moronic" pastimes such as binge drinking and visits to the City Morgue.<ref name="dcmrău"/> Stahl also protests against the [[Haussmann's renovation of Paris|Haussmannian renovation]] of downtown Bucharest, and proposes that all condemned buildings be photographed and inventoried for historical reference.<ref>{{ro icon}} Tudor Mavrodin, [http://www.revista22.ro/bucurestiul-cultural-nr-32008-4318.html "Orașul care a fost. Colțuri dintr-un București personal"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 934, February 2008</ref>
Stahl followed up with humorous [[Sketch story|sketch stories]]: ''Dela manevre'' ("From the Maneuvers"), printed by Iorga in 1912, and the 1915 ''Macabre și viceversa'' ("Macabre Ones and Vice Versa").<ref name="la&alxv335"/> He did eventually publish his science fiction novel: first in 1913, serialized in [[Victor Anestin]]'s ''[[Știință și Tehnică|Ziarul Călătoriilor]]'' magazine, then as a single volume in 1914.<ref>Manolescu, pp. 232–233; Popescu, p. 33</ref> In the latter popular edition, produced at the Bucharest Institute of Graphic Arts, the "astronomical novel" was illustrated by [[Stoica D.]] and [[Ary Murnu]].<ref>Angheluță ''et al.'', p. 335; Rd. S., p. 302</ref> At an unknown later date, Stahl also produced a volume of ''Schițe parlamentare'' ("Parliamentary Sketches"), with models of oratory, samples of ignominious behavior, and memoirs of parliamentary disputes.<ref name="schițe">{{ro icon}} [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Schite-parlamentare-ale-lui-Henri-Stahl*articleID_10128-articles_details.html "''Schițe parlamentare'' ale lui Henri Stahl"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 206, February 2004</ref>
===World War I=== During the early 1910s, Stahl made visits to the Romanian communities of [[Austria-Hungary]], and in particular to those of [[Transylvania]] and [[Partium]]. Under Germanic influence, Transylvanian Romanian intellectuals had devised their own shorthand system, codified by Vasile Vlaicu.<ref>Angheluță ''et al.'', p. 776</ref> However, Stahl was contracted by [[Romanian National Party]] leaders to record their February 1911 meeting with the constituents of [[Arad County (former)|Arad]], [[Békés County (former)|Békés]] and [[Csanád County|Csanád]] counties, which doubled as a protest against [[Magyarization]] policies and for [[universal suffrage]].<ref>Bradin, pp. 140–141, 144–145, 146–153</ref> Stahl was enthusiastic about the events, and contrasted the enthusiasm and sincerity of Transylvanians with the politicking of his Bucharest employers.<ref>Bradin, pp. 146, 148, 149–153</ref> He left notes on the "natural bond between the people and the leaders", and found the Partium peasants to be exceptionally polite, as well as "fair, intelligent, and proud".<ref>Bradin, pp. 148–149, 151</ref>
Stahl was drafted into the [[Romanian Land Forces]] in 1916, when Romania entered World War I as an enemy of Austria-Hungary. He was a reserve lieutenant in the 6th (Mihai Viteazu) Regiment.<ref name="hhs17">Stahl, p. 17</ref> He saw action during the early stages of the [[Romania in World War I|Romanian Campaign]], but was badly wounded in the trenches during the battles of September 1916.<ref name="pț66">Țurlea, p. 66</ref> Losing consciousness, he was dragged away and rescued by his peasant batman,<ref name="hhs17"/> and was under treatment at Gerota hospital when Iorga dedicated him an encomium in ''Neamul Românesc'' (September 23, 1916).<ref name="pț66"/> He was a convalescent in [[Ploiești]] when the [[Central Powers]] [[Battle of Bucharest|occupied southern Romania]].<ref>Țurlea, p. 67</ref>
Leaving his children and wife behind, Stahl escaped to [[Moldavia]], where the Romanian government authorities resided. During 1917, he resumed his collaboration with Iorga, who was putting out in [[Iași]], the provisional capital, a new review called ''[[Drum Drept]]''.<ref>Iorga, p. 253</ref> He resumed his work as stenographer, and followed Romanian parliamentarians on their refuge to Russia's [[Kherson Governorate]]. He was caught there by the [[October Revolution]], and witnessed the mounting tensions between anticommunist Romanians and [[Rumcherod]] officials.<ref name="noteulit6">"Note românești. Cu parlamentarii în U.R.S.S.", in ''[[Universul Literar]]'', Nr. 9/1942, p. 6</ref> Blanche and the Stahl children lived in occupied Bucharest, and were helped to survive by their peasant acquaintances, through contraband goods.<ref>Stahl, pp. 17–18</ref> Stahl eventually returned to the occupied capital after the [[Treaty of Bucharest (1918)|Romanian armistice]] (April 1918), and had to watch resentfully as the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]] embarked on a campaign of hasty requisitions.<ref>George Florescu, "Germania și germanii în ''Memoriile'' lui N. Iorga (1917-1918) (II)", in ''Zargidava. Revistă de Istorie'', Vol. VIII, 2009, p. 139</ref>
Stahl resumed his work in parliament after the [[First Armistice at Compiègne|German capitulation of November]]. During the late 1910s and early 1920s, he was vice president of the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Deputies' Assembly]] corps of stenographers, in which capacity he taught free lessons in stenography to university students.<ref>"Cronica bucureșteană", in ''Cultura Poporului'', Nr. 39/1923</ref> For that purpose, he issued a 1919 ''Curs de stenografie parlamentară'' ("Parliamentary Stenography Course").<ref name="la&alxv335"/> In interwar [[Greater Romania]], Stahl expanded the focus of his investigations and interviews, with trips to mountain localities such as [[Breaza]] and [[Covasna]],<ref name="hhs17"/> and resumed his literary work, in the eclectic newspaper ''[[Cuget Românesc]]''.<ref>Iorga, p. 265</ref> ''Un român în lună'' went through a second edition in 1925.<ref>Manolescu, p. 233</ref>
===Final decades=== Both of Stahl's male heirs were involved in social sciences. Known to the world as ''Șerban Voinea'' (a pseudonym he first used in 1919), Gaston became a Romanian citizen in 1929.<ref name="arhexil"/> He was a [[Theoretician (Marxism)|Marxist theoretician]], seen by Ioanid as one of "worldwide value" and a "classic of Romanian sociology",<ref name="mi41">Ioanid, p. 41</ref> whose semi-legal activities in the [[Socialist Party of Romania]] resulted in prosecution at the ''[[Dealul Spirii Trial]]''.<ref>Stahl, p. 18</ref> Living abroad during much of the 1920s, he was a graduate of several academic institutions, including the [[École supérieure de journalisme de Paris|Free College of Social Sciences]].<ref name="arhexil"/> Returning to Romania in the 1930s, Voinea primarily worked as a radio journalist, and was the theoretical voice of the [[Reformism|reformist]] and pro-Western [[Romanian Social Democratic Party (1927-1948)|Romanian Social Democratic Party]].<ref name="arhexil"/> Henri Jr was himself a student of Iorga, but not a follower, and alienated Iorga when he stated his preference for [[rural sociology]] over history.<ref>Stahl, pp. 14–15</ref> As a researcher, he brought up empirical evidence which supported some of Iorga's core theses, but criticized his attempts to silence other opponents.<ref>Stahl, pp. 15–17, 22–23, 45, 83–84, 164–165, 180</ref> Faced with financial difficulties for much of his life, he supplemented his income by working in stenography, which he had learned from his father.<ref>[[Lucian Boia]], ''Capcanele istoriei. Elita intelectuală românească între 1930 și 1950'', [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], Bucharest, 2012, p. 35. {{ISBN|978-973-50-3533-4}}; Stahl, pp. 21–22, 30–31, 110–111, 166, 201</ref>
To her father's despair, Henriette had a troubled childhood, and shunned academic life in favor of sheer experimentation.<ref>Bălaj, pp. 25–28</ref> She was, by contemporary accounts, an extraordinarily beautiful woman.<ref name="cmhysstele">{{ro icon}} Clara Mărgineanu, [http://jurnalul.ro/cultura/arte-vizuale/henriette-yvonne-stahl-printre-stele-norocoase-538571.html# "Henriette Yvonne Stahl, printre stele norocoase"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', March 15, 2010</ref> She graduated from the [[Caragiale Academy of Theatrical Arts and Cinematography|Bucharest School of Drama]], but enjoyed most acclaim as a writer. Her father encouraged her, submitting her debut novel ''Voica'' to a literary contest in 1924.<ref>{{ro icon}} Bianca Burța-Cernat, [http://www.revista22.ro/bucurestiul-cultural-nr-62008-4545.html "Din secolul trecut..."], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 949, May 2008</ref> From 1931 to 1944, Henriette was married to the poet-translator [[Ion Vinea]], and notoriously shared his passion for hard drugs, which inspired her to write violently modernist novels.<ref>Tudor Crețu, "Opiaceele Henriettei Yvonne Stahl", in ''[[Dilemateca]]'', Nr. 80, January 2013, pp. 8–12</ref>
From 1925, Stahl's expertise in graphology was harnessed by the [[National Archives of Romania]] and its Superior School of Archivists and Paleographers.<ref>Popa, pp. 24, 25. See also Stahl, p. 14</ref> Stahl's work for those years includes a 1926 textbook of graphology. It was positively reviewed at the time by the social scientist [[Mihai Ralea]], according to whom "given [Stahl's] technical expertise, nobody would have been better suited for the task than him". The textbook notably included writing samples "from virtually all of modern Romania's personalities", alongside character sketches.<ref>[[Mihai Ralea]], "Recenzii. H. Stahl, ''Grafologia''", in ''[[Viața Românească]]'', Nr. 11/1926, pp. 297–298</ref> He had also published, in 1925, the war-themed volume of sketches called ''Spion'' ("A Spy"), praised by Ralea for its authenticity.<ref>[[Mihai Ralea]], "Recenzii. H. Stahl, ''Spion''", in ''[[Viața Românească]]'', Nr. 9/1925, pp. 259–260</ref>
A second edition of ''Bucureștii ce se duc'' came out in 1935 at E. Marvan Publishers, illustrated with 175 photographs taken by Stahl himself.<ref name="dcmrău"/> Stahl published in 1936 his own contribution in the field of paleography: a textbook for [[Old Church Slavonic]], in collaboration with the Slavist Damian P. Bogdan.<ref>"Comunicate și Circulări Ministeriale. Ministerul Culturii Naționale și al Cultelor. Rapoarte privitoare la ocuparea catedrelor la Universități", in ''[[Monitorul Oficial]]'', Nr. 154/1942, pp. 5532–5533. See also Stahl, p. 14</ref> He retired from the Archivists' School in 1938, when [[Aurel Sacerdoțeanu]] took over as Director, but was still considered one of the school's prime experts, and honored by Sacerdoțeanu as the founder of Romanian graphology.<ref>Popa, pp. 25, 27</ref>
Stahl died in February 1942. This occurred during the Nazi-allied dictatorship of [[Ion Antonescu]] (to which his son Voinea was structurally opposed),<ref name="arhexil"/> while the Stahl children had come under official investigation, to decide whether the [[Antisemitic laws in Romania|racial laws]] applied to them.<ref>Mihăilescu, pp. 36–37</ref> The stenographer-historian was buried in Bucharest's [[Bellu cemetery]], the [[Roman Catholicism in Romania|Roman Catholic]] section.<ref>Gheorghe G. Bezviconi, ''Necropola Capitalei'', [[Nicolae Iorga Institute of History]], Bucharest, 1972, p. 254</ref> His death is recorded in the diary of a marginalized politician, [[Constantin Argetoianu]], right after news of [[Archibald Wavell, 1st Earl Wavell|General Wavell]]'s injury: "Death of Henri Stahl, the known stenographer. Stahl was also a remarkable writer and a very decent man. We bury with him another piece of our past, the past of old folks..."<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Constantin Argetoianu]], Stelian Neagoe, [http://jurnalul.ro/istorie-politica/din-insemnarile-zilnice-ale-lui-constantin-argetoianu-ep-39-561765.html "Din însemnările zilnice ale lui Constantin Argetoianu (ep. 39)"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', December 3, 2010</ref> Stahl's book of World War I memoirs, titled ''Cu Parlamentul în U.R.S.S.'' ("With the Parliament in the USSR"), was issued later that month, at the height of Romania's involvement in the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|anti-Soviet war]].<ref name="noteulit6"/>
==Legacy== Upon the end of the war, Stahl's two male heirs wrote Romania's first course in [[Marxist sociology]].<ref name="mi40"/> Voinea became ambassador of Romania in [[Bern]], but fell out with the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]] and defected to the West. He worked for the [[Radiodiffusion-Télévision Française|French Radio and Television Broadcasting]] and was active within the [[International Confederation of Free Trade Unions]].<ref name="arhexil"/><ref name="anro&evr"/> The other Stahls remained in Romania. Henriette's relation to Voinea resulted in the [[Censorship in Communist Romania|censoring]] of her novels, and she was banned from publishing for some 10 years.<ref>Bălaj, p. 30</ref> She was protected from imprisonment by her ten-year-long affair with [[Petru Dumitriu]], the official communist poet. When Dumitriu himself defected in 1960, Henriette was detained for several months and made to confess that she had been Dumitriu's [[ghostwriter]].<ref name="cmhysstele"/><ref>Bălaj, pp. 29–30</ref><ref name="mvbproza">{{ro icon}} Marian Victor Buciu, [http://www.romlit.ro/proza_henriettei_yvonne_stahl "Proza Henriettei Yvonne Stahl"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 7/2008</ref> She was later released, and continued to publish, in both Romania and her native France, until well into her seventies; she died in 1984.<ref name="cmhysstele"/><ref name="mvbproza"/>
Harassed by [[Securitate]] agents<ref>Mihăilescu, pp. 36–37, 41</ref> and prevented from publishing until the 1960s (during which interval he had to work in [[Systematization (Romania)|systematization]]), Henri H. Stahl was eventually allowed to join the editorial staffs of ''Biblioteca Historica Romaniae'' and ''Viitorul Social''.<ref>Ioanid, pp. 41–43</ref> He was by then lovingly married to the visual artist Margareta Stahl.<ref>Ioanid, pp. 41, 44</ref> His earlier affair with Maria Costin had produced a son, [[Paul H. Stahl]];<ref name="mi41"/> trained in sociology and art history, he escaped to France in 1969, to teach at the [[School for Advanced Studies in the Social Sciences]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Iordan Datcu, [http://www.romlit.ro/paul_h._stahl "Paul H. Stahl"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 40/2008</ref> Henri was fully reinstated after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|1989 Revolution]], and welcomed into the [[Romanian Academy]] shortly before his death, which occurred on September 9, 1991.<ref>Ioanid, p. 44</ref>
The censorship which touched his descendants under communism did not affect Henri Sr's own cultural legacy. New editions of ''Un român în lună'' saw print in 1958 and 1966.<ref>Manolescu, pp. 233, 257</ref> Years after the anticommunist revolution, the Stahl method was still being taught in stenography classes.<ref name="mi40"/> In 2002, Editura Domino put out a new version of ''Bucureștii ce se duc'', but this reissue was incomplete and lacked a critical introduction.<ref name="dcmrău"/> ''Schițe parlamentare'' was also reissued in 2003.<ref name="schițe"/>

The '''[[Portuguese language]]''' developed in the Western Iberian Peninsula from [[Latin]] spoken by [[Roman Empire|Roman]] soldiers and colonists starting in the 3rd century BC. Old Portuguese, also known as [[Galician-Portuguese]], began to diverge from other [[Romance languages]] after the [[fall of the Western Roman Empire]] and the [[Germanic people|Germanic]] invasions, also known as [[Migration Period|barbarian invasions]] in the 5th century and started appearing in written documents around the 9th century. By the 13th century, [[Galician-Portuguese]] had become a mature language with its own literature and began to split into two languages. However, the debate of whether Galician and Portuguese are nowadays varieties of the same language, much like American English or British English, is still present. In all aspects—[[phonology]], [[morphology (linguistics)|morphology]], [[lexicon]] and [[syntax]]—Portuguese is essentially the result of an organic evolution of [[Vulgar Latin]] with some influences from other languages, namely the native [[Gallaecian language|Gallaecian]] and [[Lusitanian language|Lusitanian]] languages spoken prior to the Roman domination. ==Social history== ===Romanization=== {{further|Vulgar Latin}} Arriving on the Iberian Peninsula in 218 BC, the [[ancient Rome|ancient Romans]] brought with them [[Latin language|Latin]], from which all Romance languages descend. The language was spread by arriving Roman soldiers, settlers and merchants, who built Roman cities mostly near the settlements of previous civilizations. Later, the inhabitants of the cities of [[Lusitania]] and the rest of Romanized Iberia were recognized as citizens of Rome. Roman control of the western part of Hispania was not consolidated until the campaigns of Augustus in 26 BC. Although the western territories to the south of the Tagus River were only conquered after the victory of Licinius Crassus in the year 93 BC,[http://www.arqueotavira.com/Mapas/Iberia/Populi.htm Detailed map of the Pre-Roman Peoples of Iberia (around 200 BC)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006160601/http://www.arqueotavira.com/Mapas/Iberia/Populi.htm |date=2008-10-06 }} only an estimated four hundred words of the native languages[[Portuguese vocabulary]] persist in modern Portuguese. After 200 years of wars first with the [[Ancient Carthage|Carthaginians]] in the Eastern part of the peninsula, and then the local inhabitants, emperor [[Augustus]] conquered the whole peninsula, which was named [[Hispania]]. He then divided it into three [[Roman province|provinces]], [[Hispania Tarraconensis]], [[Hispania Baetica]], and [[Lusitania]], the latter of which included most of modern Portugal. In the 3rd century, emperor [[Diocletian]] split Tarraconensis into three, creating the adjacent province of [[Gallaecia]], which geographically enclosed the remaining part of Portugal, and modern-day [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] (in the northwestern region of Spain). ===Iberian Romance=== {{main|Iberian Romance languages|Galician-Portuguese}} Between AD 409 and 711, as the Roman Empire was collapsing, the Iberian Peninsula was [[Migration Period|invaded by peoples of Germanic origin]], known by the Romans as [[Barbarians]]. The Barbarians (mainly [[Suevi]] and [[Visigoths]]) largely absorbed the Roman culture and language of the peninsula; however, since the Roman schools and administration were closed and Europe entered the [[Early Middle Ages]], the Vulgar Latin language of ordinary people was left free to evolve on its own and the uniformity of the language across the Iberian Peninsula broke down. In the north-western part of the Peninsula (today's Northern Portugal and Galicia), Vulgar Latin began gaining a growing number of local characteristics, leading to the formation of what linguists today call Galician-Portuguese. The [[Germanic languages]] influenced [[Galician-Portuguese]] by introducing words often linked to the military like ''guerra'' ([[war]]) or ''laverca'' ([[lark]]), placenames such as ([[Resende (disambiguation)|Resende]]), animals like ''ganso'' ([[goose]]), ''texugo'' ([[badger]]), human feelings such as ''orgulho'' ([[pride]]), verbs like ''brigar'' (to [[fight]]), suffixes like ''reguengo'' ([[royal domain]]) and everyday objects such as ''frasco'' ([[flask (disambiguation)|flask]]). From 711, with the [[Moors|Moorish]] invasion of the Iberian Peninsula, [[Arabic language|Arabic]] was adopted as the administrative language in the conquered regions. However, much of the population continued to speak the Latin-derived Romance dialects, called collectively by modern linguists [[Mozarabic]]. The main effect of the Arabic influence was lexical. Modern Portuguese has between 400 up to as much as 800 words of Arabic origin[https://books.google.com/books?id=GJSeK3bYGy8C&pg=PA39&dq=menos+de+mil+palavras+em+%C3%A1rabes+na+l%C3%ADngua+portuguesa&hl=pt-PT&sa=X&ei=ztliUp_QLc6VhQes54DIBg&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=menos%20de%20mil%20palavras%20em%20%C3%A1rabes%20na%20l%C3%ADngua%20portuguesa&f=false A língua portuguesa nos seus percursos multiculturais p.39] (many were absorbed indirectly through Mozarabic) especially relating to food, agriculture and the crafts, which have no cognates in other Romance languages except in Spanish from which in fact, Portuguese borrowed many of its Arabic-derived words. The Arabic influence is also visible in placenames, especially in the southern provinces, such as the [[Algarve]], [[Alfama]] and [[Fátima, Portugal|Fátima]]. However, there are no Arabic loan words in the lexicon related to human feelings or emotions; those are all of [[Latin]], [[Germanic languages|Germanic]] or [[Celtic languages|Celtic]] origin. ===Proto-Portuguese=== {| align="right" border="0" style="margin: 10px;" ! align="left" | ''Excerpt of medieval
Portuguese poetry'''''Translation:''' ''Of those I see / I desire / no other lady but you; / and a desire / so dire, / could kill a lion, / lady of my heart: / fine little rose, / prettiest over all the flowers / fine little rose, / may your love / not put me / in such a disgrace.'' |- |Das que vejo |- |non desejo |- |outra senhor se vós non, |- |e desejo |- |tan sobejo, |- |mataria um leon, |- |senhor do meu coraçon: |- |fin roseta, |- |bela sobre toda fror, |- |fin roseta, |- |non me meta |- |en tal coita voss'amor! |- |''João de Lobeira''
(1270?–1330?) |} The oldest surviving records containing written Galician-Portuguese are documents from the 9th century. In these official documents, bits of Galician-Portuguese found its way into texts that were written in Latin. Today, this phase is known as "Proto-Portuguese" simply because the earliest of these documents are from the former [[County of Portugal]], although Portuguese and Galician were still a single language. This period lasted until the 12th century. ===The lyric period=== What modern scholars call ''Galician-Portuguese'' was originally the native language of the medieval [[Kingdom of Galicia]], which was founded in 410 and included the northern part of present-day [[Portugal]]. It appears to have also been used regularly in other Christian kingdoms of the [[Iberian Peninsula]] as the language for [[Lyrics|lyric]] song. It was employed by poets from throughout the non-Basque medieval Christian kingdoms of the peninsula; including [[Kingdom of León|Leonese]], [[Castile (historical region)|Castilian]], [[Aragon]]ese and [[Catalonia|Catalan]]. It is also the language used in the ''[[Cantigas de Santa Maria]]''. These songs were traditionally attributed to [[Alfonso X]], a Castilian king, though more recent work shows that they must have been composed in collaboration with many translators, poets and musicians. ===The divergence of Galician-Portuguese=== Portugal was formally recognized as an independent kingdom in 1143 by the [[Kingdom of León]], into which Galicia was incorporated at the time, with [[Alfonso I of Portugal|Afonso Henriques]] as its first king. In 1290, King [[Denis of Portugal|Diniz]] created the first Portuguese University in Lisbon (the ''Estudo Geral'') and decreed that the language of the Portuguese, then simply called the "Vulgar language" (i.e. [[Vulgar Latin]]) should be used in preference to [[Latin]] and known as the "Portuguese language". In 1296, Portuguese was adopted by the Royal Chancellary and was used not only in poetry but also when writing law and in notaries. In the first period of "Old Portuguese" (from 12th to the 14th century), the language came gradually to be used in official documents. With the political separation of the County of Portugal from Galicia, Galician-Portuguese lost its unity and slowly became two increasingly distinct languages. This growing difference accelerated when Galicia became part of Castile and Galician was increasingly influenced by Castilian. Meanwhile, the southern variant of Galician-Portuguese became the modern Portuguese language within the [[Kingdom of Portugal]] and its empire. ==Standardization during the Renaissance== {{See also|Portuguese vocabulary}} The end of "Old Portuguese" was marked by the publication of the ''Cancioneiro Geral'' by [[Garcia de Resende]], in 1516. "Modern Portuguese" developed from the early 16th century to the present. During the [[Renaissance]], scholars and writers borrowed many words from [[classical Latin]] (learned words borrowed from Latin also came from [[Renaissance Latin]]) and [[ancient Greek]], which increased the complexity of the Portuguese [[lexicon]]. Most literate Portuguese speakers were also literate in Latin; and thus they easily adopted Latin words into their writing—and eventually speech—in Portuguese.{{cn|date=March 2017}} As with most European [[vernacular language]]s, the standardization of the Portuguese language was propelled by the development of the [[printing press]]. In 1536 [[Fernão de Oliveira]] published his ''Grammatica da lingoagem portuguesa'' in Lisbon, the first [[Portuguese grammar]].{{cite web|url=http://purl.pt/369/1/ficha-obra-gramatica.html|website=Tesouros impressos da Biblioteca Nacional|title=Grammatica da lingoagem Portuguesa de Fernão de Oliveira}}{{Cite book|title = Portuguese: A linguistic introduction|last = Azevedo|first = Milton M.|publisher = Cambridge University Press|year = 2005|isbn = 978-0-521-80515-5|location = Cambridge|page = 13|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tWk6gpv8ep0C&pg=PA13}} The work of this heterodox Dominican priest, philologist and mariner was soon followed. In 1540, [[João de Barros]] crown officer published his ''Gramática da Língua Portuguesa'' along with moral dialogues and basics of the Catholic Church to help teaching young aristocrats.Cantarino, Nelson. ''O idioma nosso de cada dia'', in: Revista de História da Biblioteca Nacional, ano 1, nº 8, fev/mar 2006 (Seção: Documento Por Dentro da Biblioteca) – [http://www.revistadehistoria.com.br/v2/home/?go=detalhe&id=941 Texto parcial] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121208183539/http://www.revistadehistoria.com.br/v2/home/?go=detalhe&id=941 |date=2012-12-08 }}, sítio obtido em 31 de janeiro de 2008. This second work, illustrated with woodcuts, is considered the world's first printed illustrated [[text book]]. ===Expansion during the age of discovery=== {{See also|Portuguese vocabulary}} The second period of Old Portuguese covers the time from the 14th to the 16th centuries and is marked by the Portuguese discoveries of the 15th and 16th centuries. In that time, colonisers, traders and missionaries spread the Portuguese language to many regions in [[Africa]], [[Asia]] and [[The Americas]]. Today most Portuguese speakers live in Brazil, the biggest former colony of Portugal. By the mid-16th century, Portuguese had become a ''[[lingua franca]]'' in Asia and Africa, used not only for colonial administration and trade but also for communication between local officials and Europeans of all nationalities. In Ceylon (modern [[Sri Lanka]]) several kings became fluent speakers of Portuguese, and nobles often took Portuguese names. The spread of the language was helped by its association with the [[Catholic]] [[missionary]] efforts, which led to its being called ''Cristão'' ("[[Christianity|Christian]]") in many places. The ''[[Nippo Jisho]]'', a Japanese–Portuguese dictionary written in 1603, was a product of [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] missionary activity in [[Japan]]. The language continued to be popular in parts of Asia until the 19th century, despite the severe measures taken by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] to abolish it in Ceylon and [[Indonesia]]. Some Portuguese-speaking Christian communities in [[India]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Malaysia]] and [[Indonesia]] preserved their language even after they were isolated from Portugal. The language has largely changed in these communities and has evolved through the centuries into several [[Portuguese Creole|Portuguese creoles]]. Also, a considerable number of words of Portuguese origin are found in [[Tetum]], the national language of [[East Timor]], such as ''lee'' "[[reading (activity)|to read]]" (from ''ler''), ''aprende'' "[[learning|to learn]]" (from ''aprender'') and ''tenke'' "to have to" (from ''tem que''). Portuguese words entered the lexicons of many other languages, such as ''pan'' "[[bread]]" (from ''pão'') in [[Japanese language|Japanese]] (see [[Japanese words of Portuguese origin]]), ''sepatu'' "[[shoe]]" (from ''sapato'') in [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]], ''keju'' "[[cheese]]" (from ''queijo'') in [[Malay language|Malay]] and ''meza'' "[[Table (furniture)|table]]" (from ''mesa'') in [[Swahili language|Swahili]]. Due to the vast expanse of the [[Portuguese Empire]], there are also numerous words that entered English (see: [[List of English words of Portuguese origin]]) such as ''albino'', ''[[baroque]]'', ''mosquito'', ''potato'', ''savvy'' and ''zebra''. == Historical sound changes == {{unreferencedsection|date=September 2017}} Both in [[morphology (linguistics)|morphology]] and in [[syntax]], Portuguese represents an organic transformation of [[Latin]] without the direct intervention of any foreign language. The sounds, grammatical forms, and syntactical types, with a few exceptions, are derived from Latin, and almost 80% of its vocabulary is still derived from the language of Rome. Some of the changes began during the [[Roman Empire|Empire]], others took place later. A few words remained virtually unchanged, like ''carro'', ''taberna'' ("tavern"), or even returned to a form close to the original, such as ''coxa'' ("thigh") – in this case, however, only the spelling looks identical: Latin ⟨''x''⟩ and Portuguese ⟨''x''⟩ designate two completely different sounds, {{IPA|[ks]}} and {{IPA|[ʃ]}} respectively. Learned [[Latinism]]s were formed in the late Middle Ages, due to the use of [[Church Latin]] by the [[Catholic Church]], and during the [[Renaissance]], when [[Classical antiquity]] in general, and [[Classical Latin|Literary Latin]] in particular, enjoyed great prestige. Thus, for example, Latin ''aurum'', which had originated ''ouro'' ("gold") and ''dourado'' ("golden"), was re-introduced as the adjective ''áureo'' ("golden"). In the same way, ''locālem'' ("place"), which had evolved to ''lugar'', was later reintroduced as the more erudite ''local''. Many erudite [[Greek language|Greek]] words and combining elements were also introduced or reintroduced in this way. Because of this, many Latin words are still familiar to Portuguese speakers. The letter ⟨''v''⟩ was the vowel we know today as ⟨''u''⟩, and ⟨''c''⟩ was always pronounced {{IPA|[k]}}, so ''centum'' was originally pronounced {{IPA|[ˈkentũ]}}. Later Latinisms are marked with (L). ===Palatalization=== [[Palatalization (sound change)|Palatalization]] of voiceless stops—the consonants {{IPA|[k]}} and {{IPA|[t]}} assimilated with the high vowels {{IPA|[e]}} and {{IPA|[i]}}, and with the semivowel {{IPA|[j]}}.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} * ''centum'' > {{IPA|[tj]}}''ento'' > {{IPA|[ts]}}''ento'' > {{IPA|[s]}}''ento'' (hundred){{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} * ''facere'' > ''fa''{{IPA|[tj]}}''ere'' > ''fa''{{IPA|[ts]}}''er'' > ''fa''{{IPA|[dz]}}''er'' > ''fa''{{IPA|[z]}}''er'' (to do) A more ancient evolution was * ''fortiam'' > ''for''{{IPA|[ts]}}''a'' > ''for''{{IPA|[s]}}''a'' (strength) ===Voicing=== [[Phonation|Voicing]]—some consonants did not disappear but rather evolved with voiceless stops becoming voiced stops and voiced stops becoming voiced fricatives in certain positions, a common type of [[Assimilation (linguistics)|sound change]]: * ''mūtum'' > ''mudo'' (mute) * ''lacum'' > ''lago'' (lake) * ''locustam'' > ''lagosta'' (lobster) ===Lenition=== [[Lenition (linguistics)|Lenition]]—consonant clusters, especially long (geminate) consonants, were simplified: * ''guttam'' > ''gota'' (drop) * ''quatturo'' > ''quatro'' (four) * ''peccāre'' > ''pecar'' (to sin) Phoneme [b] evolved as [v]. The {{IPA|/v/}} phoneme was generally derived either (1) from an allophone of Latin {{IPA|/b/}} between vowels or (2) from the Latin phoneme corresponding to the letter ⟨v⟩ (pronounced {{IPA|[w]}} in Classical Latin, but later [[Fortition|fortified]] to the status of a [[fricative consonant]] in Vulgar Latin). *''habēre'' > ''haver'' * ''fabam'' > ''fava'' (broad bean) *''amābam/amābat'' > ''amava'' *''līber, lībri'' > ''livro'' *''parabola'' > ''palavra'' ===Elision=== [[Elision]]—the consonants {{IPA|[l]}} and {{IPA|[n]}} of [[Vulgar Latin]] were deleted between vowels, after which sometimes the vowels around them coalesced, or an epenthetic semivowel was introduced between them. Original geminates {{IPA|[ll]}}, {{IPA|[nn]}} persisted, later becoming single {{IPA|[l]}}, {{IPA|[n]}}. * ''dolōrem'' > ''door'' > ''dor'' (pain); (L) ''doloroso'' (painful) * ''bonum'' > ''bõo'' > ''bom'' (good) * ''ānellum'' > ''ãelo'' > ''elo'' (bond); (L) ''anel'' (ring) * ''salīre'' > ''sair'' (to get out) * ''cōlāre'' > ''coar'' (sift) * ''notulam'' > ''nódoa'' (stain) * ''catēnam'' > ''cadeia'' (jail, chain); (L) ''cadena'' (jail, chain) (more erudite) ===Palatalization=== [[Palatalization (sound change)|Palatalization]] of liquids and nasals—the consonants {{IPA|[l]}} and {{IPA|[n]}} assimilated with the semivowel {{IPA|[j]}}, producing the palatals ''lh'' {{IPA|[ʎ]}} and ''nh'' {{IPA|[ɲ]}}: * ''mulierem'' > ''mulher'' (woman) * ''iūnium'' > ''junho'' (June) ===Nasalization=== In medieval [[Galician-Portuguese]], {{IPA|/m/}} and {{IPA|/n/}} between vowels or at the end of a syllable became the velar nasal phoneme {{IPA|/ŋ/}}, leading to regressive nasalization of the preceding vowel as a secondary phonetic effect.{{cite web|url=https://ruc.udc.es/dspace/handle/2183/2595|title=Existe rima de vogal aberta com vogal fechada na poesia trovadoresca galego-portuguesa|first=José Martinho|last=Montero Santalha|year=2002|journal=Revista Galega de Filoloxía|volume=3|pages=107-143|issn=1576-2661|publisher=Universidade da Coruña}} This consonant was then at a later stage lost or modified in Portuguese, although it was retained in [[Galician language|Galician]] in some words (e.g. modern ''unha'' ({{IPA|/uŋa/}}) identical in pronunciation to medieval ''hũa''). This change produced one of the most striking phonological differences between Portuguese and Spanish. The history of nasal vowels in hiatus with a previous or following vowel is complex, depending on the identity of the two vowels and the position of the stress. 1. If the vowels were near each other, they collapsed into a single vowel (nasal or oral, according to the nasality of the stressed vowel): * ''bonum'' > ''bõo'' > ''bom'' (good ''masc.'') * ''calentem'' > ''caẽte'' > ''quente'' (hot) * ''ganātum'' > ''gãado'' > ''gado'' (cattle) * ''lānam'' > ''lãa'' > ''lã'' (wool) 2. Otherwise, if the second vowel was more closed, the result was usually a nasal diphthong: * ''manum'' > ''mão'' (hand) * ''canem'' > ''cães'' (dogs) 3. If the second vowel was more open, or as open, nasalization was lost: * ''lūnam'' > ''lũa'' > ''lua'' (moon). Exception: ''ūnam'' > ''ũa'' > ''uma'' (one) * ''bonam'' > ''bõa'' > ''boa'' (good ''fem.'') * ''plēnum'' > ''chẽo'' > ''cheio'' (full); (L) ''pleno'' (full) 4. If the first vowel was {{IPA|[i]}}, however, nasalization evolved to a [[palatal nasal]] consonant, inserted between the two vowels: * ''vīnum'' > ''vĩo'' > ''vinho'' (wine) * ''rēgīnam'' > ''*ragina'' > ''raĩa'' > rainha (queen) Progressive [[nasalization]]—The spread of nasalization forward from a nasal consonant, especially {{IPA|[m]}}. * ''mātrem'' > ''made'' > ''mai'' > ''mãe'' (mother) * ''meam'' > ''mia'' > ''mĩa'' > ''minha'' (my ''fem.''); but compare ''meum'' > ''meu'' (my ''masc.'') * ''ad noctem'' > ''anoite'' > ''ãote'' > ''ontem'' {{IPA|[ˈõtẽĩ]}} (yesterday). ===Epenthesis=== [[Epenthesis]]—the insertion of a sound to break up a combination of vowels which was difficult to pronounce: * ''harēnam'' > ''arẽa'' > ''areia'' (sand); (L) ''arena'' (arena) * ''gallīnam'' > ''galĩa'' > ''galinha'' (chicken) * ''vīnum'' > ''vĩo'' > ''vinho'' (wine) Examples such as the former two have been used by some authors to argue that the digraph ''nh'' was a nasal approximant in medieval Portuguese, and thus its pronunciation {{IPA|[j̃]}} in most dialects of Brazil and São Tomé and Príncipe is the original one.Rosa Mattos e Silva, ''O Português arcaico – fonologia'', Contexto, 1991, p.73. ===Dissimilation=== [[Dissimilation]]—Modification of a sound by the influence of neighbouring sounds; similar became different over time, so as to ease pronunciation. 1. Between vowels: * ''locustam'' > ''lagosta'' (lobster) * ''campanam'' > ''campãa'' > ''campa'' (tomb) 2. Between consonants: * ''memorāre'' > ''nembrar'' > ''lembrar'' (to remember); (L) ''memorizar'' (to memorize) * ''animam'' > ''alma'' (soul); (L) ''animado'' (animated) * ''locālem'' > ''logar'' > ''lugar''; (L) ''local'' (place) ===Metathesis=== [[Metathesis (linguistics)|Metathesis]]—a sound change that alters the order of phonemes in a word. Semi-vowel metathesis: * ''prīmārium'' > ''primeiro'' (first); (L) ''primário'' (primary) Consonant metathesis in {{IPA|[l]}} and {{IPA|[ɾ]}}: * ''tenebrās'' > ''tẽevras'' > ''trevas'' (darkness); this was rare in Portuguese; (L) ''tenebroso'' (dark) Vowel metathesis: * ''genuculum'' > ''*genoclo'' > ''gẽolho'' > ''joelho'' (knee) ===Medieval sound changes=== {{unreferenced|date=September 2017}} [[Old Portuguese]] had seven sibilants: [[lamino-alveolar]] affricates {{IPA|/ts/}} (⟨''c''⟩ before ⟨''e/i''⟩, ⟨''ç''⟩ elsewhere) and {{IPA|/dz/}} (⟨''z''⟩); [[apico-alveolar]] fricatives {{IPA|/s/}} (⟨''s''⟩, or ⟨''ss''⟩ between vowels) and {{IPA|/z/}} (⟨''s''⟩ between vowels); [[palato-alveolar]] fricatives {{IPA|/ʃ/}} (⟨''x''⟩) and {{IPA|/ʒ/}}, earlier {{IPA|/dʒ/}} (⟨''j''⟩, also ⟨''g''⟩ before ⟨''e/i''⟩); and [[palato-alveolar]] affricate {{IPA|/tʃ/}} (⟨''ch''⟩). This system was identical to the system of [[Old Spanish]], and Portuguese followed the same path as Old Spanish in deaffricating the sibilants {{IPA|/ts/}} and {{IPA|/dz/}} into lamino-alveolar fricatives that still remained distinct from the apico-alveolar consonants. This produced a system of six fricatives and one affricate, which is still maintained in small parts of northeast Portuguese province of [[Trás-os-Montes Province|Trás-os-Montes]] and in the adjacent [[Mirandese language]]; but in most places, these seven sounds have been reduced to four. Everywhere except in the above-mentioned parts of Trás-os-Montes, the lamino-alveolar and apico-alveolar fricatives merged. (This appears to have happened no earlier than the seventeenth century, on the evidence of the spelling system used by [[Alexandre de Rhodes]] to represent [[Middle Vietnamese]]). In northern Portugal and [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], they became apico-alveolars (as in the central and northern peninsular Spanish pronunciation of {{IPA|/s/}}). In most of Brazil, they became lamino-alveolar consonants (as in the English pronunciation of {{IPA|/s/}} and {{IPA|/z/}}). In central and southern Portugal (and in [[Rio de Janeiro]] and surrounding areas, due to the relocation of the Portuguese nobility in the early 1800s), they merged as lamino-alveolars before vowels, but as palato-alveolar {{IPA|/ʃ ʒ/}} elsewhere. Meanwhile, {{IPA|/tʃ/}} eventually lost its affrication and merged with {{IPA|/ʃ/}}, although {{IPA|/tʃ/}} is maintained throughout Trás-os-Montes. It appears that the sound written ⟨''v''⟩ was at one point during the medieval period pronounced as a [[voiced bilabial fricative]] {{IPA|[β]}}. Subsequently, it either changed into a labiodental fricative {{IPA|[v]}} (as in central and southern Portugal, and hence in Brazil), or merged into {{IPA|/b/}} (as in northern Portugal and Galicia, similarly to modern Spanish). Also similarly to modern Spanish, the voiced stops {{IPA|/b d ɡ/}} eventually became pronounced as fricatives {{IPA|[β ð ɣ]}} between vowels and after consonants, other than in the clusters {{IPA|/nd/ /ld/ /nɡ/ /mb/}} (the nasals were presumably still pronounced in these clusters, rather than simply reflected as a nasal vowel). However, this change happened after the colonization of Brazil, and never affected [[Brazilian Portuguese]]. Final unstressed {{IPA|/a/}} was subsequently raised to {{IPA|/ɐ/}}. Final {{IPA|/o/}} was eventually raised to {{IPA|/u/}} in both Portugal and Brazil, but independently. Final unstressed {{IPA|/e/}} was likewise raised to {{IPA|/i/}} in Brazil, but shifted to {{IPA|/ɨ/}} in Portugal (now barely pronounced). In Portugal (but not in Brazil), these changes have come to affect almost all unstressed instances of {{IPA|/a/ /o/ /e/}}; but not {{IPA|/ou/}} (which now appears as {{IPA|/o/}}), nor the former sequences {{IPA|/aa/}} {{IPA|/ee/}} {{IPA|/oo/}} (which now appear as {{IPA|/a/ /ɛ/ /ɔ/}} respectively), nor in syllables closed by stop consonants (e.g. in ''secção'' "section", ''optar'' "to choose"). Hence in Portugal ''pesar'' "to weigh" {{IPA|/pɨzaɾ/}} but ''pregar'' "to preach" {{IPA|/prɛɡaɾ/}} (former ''preegar'' < ''praedicāre''); ''morar'' "to live" {{IPA|/muɾaɾ/}}, but ''corado'' "blushing" {{IPA|/kɔɾadu/}} (former ''coorado'' < ''colōrātum''), ''roubar'' "to rob" {{IPA|/ʁobaɾ/}}. (In Brazil these appear as {{IPA|/pezax/, /preɡax/, /moɾax/, /koɾadu/, /xo(u)bax/}}.) Recently in Rio de Janeiro (and rapidly spreading to other parts of Brazil), {{IPA|/t/}} and {{IPA|/d/}} have been affricated to {{IPA|/tʃ/}} and {{IPA|/dʒ/}} before {{IPA|/i/}}, including {{IPA|/i/}} from unstressed {{IPA|/e/}}. Old Portuguese had a large number of occurrences of hiatus (two vowels next to each other with no consonant in between), as a result of the loss of Latin {{IPA|/l n d ɡ/}} between vowels. In the transition to modern Portuguese, these were resolved in a complex but largely regular fashion, either remaining, compressing into a single vowel, turning into a diphthong, or gaining an epenthetic consonant such as {{IPA|/v/}} or {{IPA|/ɲ/}}; see above. Portuguese traditionally had two alveolar rhotic consonants, a flap {{IPA|/ɾ/}} and trill {{IPA|/r/}}, as in Spanish. In most areas of Portugal the trill {{IPA|/r/}} has passed into a uvular fricative {{IPA|/ʁ/}}. In most parts of Brazil, however, {{IPA|/r/}} has become an ''unvoiced'' fricative {{IPA|/x/}} (variously {{IPA|[x χ h]}}), and all instances of {{IPA|/ɾ/}} not preceding a vowel have been likewise affected. (When final, this sound is sometimes not pronounced at all.) {{IPA|/l/}} at the end of a syllable became heavily [[velarized]] {{IPA|/ɫ/}} in Portuguese. This still remains in Portugal, but in Brazil has progressed further, merging into {{IPA|/w/}}. ==See also== * [[Differences between Spanish and Portuguese]] * [[Galician language]] * [[History of Galicia]] * [[History of Portugal]] * [[History of Brazil]] * [[List of English words of Portuguese origin]] * [[Portuguese vocabulary]] * [[Romance languages]] * [[Spelling reforms of Portuguese]] * [[Museum of the Portuguese Language]] * [[Portuguese Language Orthographic Agreement of 1990]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.deltatranslator.com/delta/port_history.htm History of Portuguese] * [http://www.deltatranslator.com/delta/recent_changes.htm Changes to the Portuguese Language] {{Language histories}} {{DEFAULTSORT:History Of Portuguese}} [[Category:Language histories|Portuguese]] [[Category:Portuguese language]]

page.title: International Book Fair of Radical Black and Third World Books

revision.text:
'''The International Book Fair of Radical Black and Third World Books''', often referred to as '''The Black Book Fair''',<ref>[[Margaret Busby]], [http://www.georgepadmoreinstitute.org/published-pieces "John La Rose Obituary"], in ''Publishing News'', 2006. Reprinted on [[George Padmore Institute]] website.</ref><ref>[http://guyanachronicle.com/preserving-our-literary-heritage-janice-lowe-shinebourne-an-enabling-literary-culture-part-2/ "Preserving our literary heritage – Janice Lowe Shinebourne – An Enabling Literary Culture (part 2)"], ''Guyana Chronicle'', 13 April 2013.</ref> was inaugurated in [[London]], [[England]], in April 1982 and continued until 1995,<ref>Gus John, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nbGcAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA684&lpg=PA684&dq=%22international+book+fair+of+radical+black+and+third+world+books%22&source=bl&ots=FVyZ8vxA7k&sig=HAsU4tsDP6aDi3Ymm_-TIJXb82A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFEQ6AEwC2oVChMIuZiOpeqVyAIVBb4UCh0aswY6#v=onepage&q=%22international%20book%20fair%20of%20radical%20black%20and%20third%20world%20books%22&f=false "La Rose, John Anthony"] in Lawrence Goldman (ed.), ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography 2005-2008'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, p. 684.</ref> bringing together a number of Black publishers, intellectuals and educationalists.<ref>Elizabeth M. Williams, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=d18TBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA167&lpg=PA167&dq=%22international+book+fair+of+radical+black+and+third+world+books%22&source=bl&ots=guDxLGYf57&sig=_QFMFqw6ojT6GGkgmRaztfK13N0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFkQ6AEwDmoVChMIuZiOpeqVyAIVBb4UCh0aswY6#v=onepage&q=%22international%20book%20fair%20of%20radical%20black%20and%20third%20world%20books%22&f=false ''The Politics of Race in Britain and South Africa: Black British Solidarity and the Anti-apartheid Struggle''], I.B. Tauris, 2015, p. 167.</ref> It was held on 12 occasions: annually from 1982 to 1991, and then biannually in 1993 and 1995.<ref name=Catalogue>[http://www.georgepadmoreinstitute.org/archive/collection/international-book-fairs "The International Book Fairs"], George Padmore Institute, Archive Catalogue.</ref> The first three Book Fairs took place in different areas of London — [[Islington]], [[Lambeth]] and [[Acton, London|Acton]] — representing the respective bases of the three founding organisers: [[New Beacon Books]], [[Race Today|Race Today Publications]] and [[Bogle-L'Ouverture Publications]].<ref name=Meeting>Sarah White, Roxy Harris & Sharmilla Beezmohun (eds), ''A Meeting of the Continents: The International Book Fair of Radical Black and Third World Books – Revisited'', London: New Beacon Books/George Padmore Institute, 2005, p. vi.</ref> Additionally, from 1985, there were associated book fairs held elsewhere in [[England]], in [[Manchester]] (1985–91, 1995) and [[Bradford]] (1985–93), [[Leeds]] (1993, 1995), and in 1993 and 1995 in [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]].<ref>[http://www.georgepadmoreinstitute.org/archive/collection/international-book-fairs "The International Book Fairs"], George Padmore Institute Archive Catalogue.</ref> In 1987 and 1988, a sister event — the Caribbean Peoples International Bookfair and Bookfair Festival — took place in [[Trinidad and Tobago|Trinidad]], organised by the [[Oilfields Workers Trade Union]] there.<ref name=Meeting />
The ethos of the Book Fair was "to mark the new and expanding phase in the growth of radical ideas and concepts, and their expression in literature, politics, music, art and social life."<ref>Angela Enisuoh, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=VfdpdZ9DwH0C&pg=PA153&lpg=PA153&dq=%22international+book+fair+of+radical+black+and+third+world+books%22&source=bl&ots=n9EUr7mK5J&sig=sF6-qZHeUYlmbSbOkykK-qjuSbE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEYQ6AEwB2oVChMIudDj_ZWYyAIVQT8aCh0JQAl1#v=onepage&q=%22international%20book%20fair%20of%20radical%20black%20and%20third%20world%20books%22&f=false "International Book Fair of Radical Black and Third World Books"], in [[Alison Donnell]], ''Companion to Contemporary Black British Culture'', Routledge, 2002, p. 153.</ref>
==History== The idea for an annual book fair was mooted in discussions after an event at the [[Commonwealth Institute]] in 1979 to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the founding by [[Jessica Huntley (publisher)|Jessica Huntley]] and Eric Huntley of [[Bogle-L'Ouverture Publications]]; described as a "cultural extravaganza", it featured a variety of performers, poets, drummers, dancers and musicians, including [[Misty in Roots]], [[Keith Waithe]], [[Cecil Rajendra]], [[Linton Kwesi Johnson]] and others. Its success demonstrated "the potential for an event on this scale taking place in different parts of London and the UK on a regular basis", and the suggestion of an annual book fair was later developed and eventually implemented.<ref>Margaret Andrews, ''Doing Nothing is Not An Option: The Radical Lives of Eric & Jessica Huntley'', Middlesex, England: Krik Krak, 2014, pp. 141–142. {{ISBN|978-1-908415-02-8}}.</ref><ref>Robin Bunce and Paul Field, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=t_0pBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA188&lpg=PA188&dq=international+book+fair+of+radical+black+and+third+world+books+april&source=bl&ots=hMlp3CIaz7&sig=M3uflsKBxvNfTrNHSGq9GB4XgOE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CJABEOgBMBdqFQoTCPDe-9LUmcgCFUg4GgodvtMOZw#v=onepage&q=international%20book%20fair%20of%20radical%20black%20and%20third%20world%20books%20april&f=false ''Darcus Howe: A Political Biography''], [[Bloomsbury Publishing]], 2015, p. 188.</ref>
The International Book Fair of Radical Black and Third World Books was established by [[Bogle-L'Ouverture Publications]], [[New Beacon Books]] and the [[Race Today]] collective in 1982,<ref>Heiba Lamara, [http://www.racecard.org.uk/history/deep-roots-a-story-of-black-british-publishing/ "Deep Roots – a story of Black British Publishing"], Racecard, 10 February 2014.</ref> with the aim of being a "meeting of the continents for writers, publishers, distributors, booksellers, artists, musicians, film makers, and the people who inspire and consume their creative productions".<ref name=Meeting /> The joint directors were [[John La Rose]] and Jessica Huntley until 1984, after which La Rose continued as sole director.<ref>[http://www.georgepadmoreinstitute.org/John%20La%20Rose "John La Rose"], George Padmore Institute.</ref><ref>Linton Kwesi Johnson, [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/mar/04/guardianobituaries.socialexclusion "John La Rose" (obituary)], ''The Guardian'', 4 March 2006.</ref>
The first Book Fair was opened at [[Islington Town Hall]] on Thursday, 1 April 1982, by [[C. L. R. James]] (1982),<ref>''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, p. 89.</ref> and subsequent years saw other literary figures make the opening address, including [[Edward Kamau Brathwaite]] (1984),<ref>''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, p. 169.</ref> [[Wole Soyinka]] (1985),<ref>"The Nkomati Years", in ''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, p. 233.</ref>[[Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o]] (1987),<ref>''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, pp. 277, 302–03.</ref><ref>Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Wml93dC12FQC&pg=PA113&lpg=PA113&dq=%22international+book+fair+of+radical+black+and+third+world+books%22&source=bl&ots=ilWmTMc5nC&sig=ocSalO3hRI934LT2M3liXGK2kBA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFMQ6AEwDGoVChMIrqCOy9WZyAIVxQgaCh1a_g03#v=onepage&q=%22international%20book%20fair%20of%20radical%20black%20and%20third%20world%20books%22&f=false ''Moving the Centre: The Struggle for Cultural Freedoms''], James Currey Publishers, 1993, pp. 109, 113.</ref> [[Abdul Alkalimat]] (1988),<ref>''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, pp. 340–341.</ref> [[Farrukh Dhondy]] (1989),<ref>Farrukh Dhondy, "A Satanic Sermon", in ''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, pp. 384–387.</ref> [[Jayne Cortez]] (1990),<ref>"Opening Address given by Jayne Cortez at the 9th International Book Fair of Radical Black and Third World Books, at the Camden Centre on Thursday March 22nd 1990", ''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, pp. 421–422.</ref> John La Rose (1991),<ref>''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, pp. 435.</ref> [[Margaret Busby]] (1993),<ref>"Address of Margaret Busby to the opening of the 11th International Book Fair on Thursday March 25th 1993", ''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, pp. 499–500.</ref> and [[Pearl Connor]] (1995).<ref>"Pearl Connor-Mogotsi", ''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, p. 509.</ref>
The book fair itself took place on a Thursday, Friday and Saturday, with cultural and political forums<ref name=Thomas>Dominic Thomas (ed.), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YOWmBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&dq=%22international+book+fair+of+radical+black+and+third+world+books%22&source=bl&ots=FjdxNKxwBx&sig=-ma6C_Y_eJi78MTxv2lmdWTGmNA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBmoVChMIudDj_ZWYyAIVQT8aCh0JQAl1#v=onepage&q=%22international%20book%20fair%20of%20radical%20black%20and%20third%20world%20books%22&f=false ''Afroeuropean Cartographies''], Cambridge Scholars Publishing, 2014, p. 18.</ref> and other events in the preceding days of the week, and a closing concert on the following Sunday. The first Book Fair week in 1982 was attended by some 6,000 people.<ref>Brian Alleyne, [http://humanhacker.net/?p=81 "Remembering Jhohn La Rose (1927–2006)"], Human Hacker, 7 March 2007.</ref> Topics covered in the forums included a discussion in 1982, with Jessica Huntley as presenter, on "Racist and fascist attacks on Black, left-wing and community booksellers and other institutions in Britain",<ref>"Programme of Events", ''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, p. 91.</ref> or, in 1984, a forum entitled "Migrant Struggles in Britain and Europe", chaired by [[Darcus Howe]].<ref name=Thomas />
Those who attended the Book Fair came from the Caribbean, Africa, Asia, Central America, the US, as well as the UK and other parts of Europe, not only to exhibit, order and distribute books but to take part in the accompanying programme of events that, alongside political discussion, showcased different cultural presentations including poetry and prose readings, drama, music and film.<ref name=Catalogue /> The many notable participants over the years included [[John Agard]], [[Ama Ata Aidoo]], [[Tariq Ali]], [[May Ayim]], [[Imruh Bakari]], [[Biyi Bandele]], [[Amiri Baraka]], [[James Berry (poet)|James Berry]], [[Valerie Bloom]], [[Jean Binta Breeze]], [[Yvonne Brewster]], [[Dennis Brutus]], [[Robert Chrisman]], [[Merle Collins]], [[Carolyn Cooper]], [[Fred D'Aguiar]], [[Melvin Edwards]], [[Nuruddin Farah]], [[Edouard Glissant]], [[Lorna Goodison]], [[Roy A. K. Heath]], [[Tim Hector]], [[bell hooks]], [[Gus John]], [[Linton Kwesi Johnson]], [[June Jordan]], [[Jackie Kay]], [[Shake Keane]], [[James Kelman]], [[Talib Kibwe]], [[Errol Lloyd]], [[Earl Lovelace]], [[Jack Mapanje]], [[E. A. Markham]], [[Paule Marshall]], [[Pauline Melville]], [[Louise Meriwether]], [[Adrian Mitchell]], [[Nancy Morejon]], [[Lionel Ngakane]], [[Pitika Ntuli]], [[Odia Ofeimun]], [[Olu Oguibe]], [[Ben Okri]], [[Kole Omotoso]], [[Oku Onuora]], [[Horace Ové]], [[Alex Pascall]], [[Okot p'Bitek]], [[Caryl Phillips]], [[John Pilger]], [[Cecil Rajendra]], [[Sonia Sanchez]], [[Lawrence Scott]], [[Mongane Wally Serote]], [[Janice Shinebourne]], [[Lemn Sissay]], [[Mikey Smith]], [[Eintou Pearl Springer|Pearl Springer]], [[Wangui wa Goro]], and [[Randy Weston]].<ref>White, Harris & Beezmohun (eds), ''A Meeting of the Continents: The International Book Fair of Radical Black and Third World Books – Revisited'', 2005.</ref>
In February 1997, a decision was taken by the Director and the Organising Committee of the Book Fair not to continue with it in its then form, proposing instead other future events in the Book Fair tradition, including the development of the [[George Padmore Institute]].<ref>"Statement: The International Book Fair of Radical Black and Third World Books", ''A Meeting of the Continents'', 2005, p. 22.</ref>
==Further reading== * Sarah White, Roxy Harris & Sharmilla Beezmohun (eds), ''A Meeting of the Continents: The International Book Fair of Radical Black and Third World Books – Revisited'', London: New Beacon Books/George Padmore Institute, 2005. {{ISBN|978-1873201183}}.

{{Periods in English History}} The '''Interregnum''' was the period between the [[execution of Charles I]] on 30 January 1649 and the arrival of his son [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] in London on 29 May 1660 which marked the start of the [[Restoration (England)|Restoration]]. During the Interregnum England was under various forms of republican government (see [[Commonwealth of England]]; this article describes other facets of the Interregnum).
==Politics== {{main|Commonwealth of England}} The politics of the period were dominated by the wishes of the ''[[Grandee (New Model Army)|Grandee]]s'' (Senior Officers) of the [[New Model Army]] and their civilian supporters. They encouraged (or at least tolerated) several republican regimes.
From 1649 until 1653 executive powers lay with [[Council of State (England)|Council of State]], while legislative functions were carried out by the [[Rump Parliament]].
In 1653 the Grandees, with [[Oliver Cromwell]] in the lead, dismissed the Rump, and replaced it with a Nominated Assembly (nicknamed the Parliament of Saints and [[Barebone's Parliament]]) made up of 140 nominees, 129 from England, five from Scotland and six from Ireland. It proved to be as difficult for the executive to work with this parliament as it had with the Rump, so, after sitting for five months, members friendly to the Grandees engendered its dissolution on 12 December 1653.
The ''[[Instrument of Government]]'' was adopted on 15 December 1653 and the pre-eminent ''Grandee'' [[Oliver Cromwell]] was installed as [[Lord Protector]] on the following day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/240140/Instrument-of-Government|title=Instrument of Government|work=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> The ''Instrument of Government'' granted [[executive power]] to the [[Lord Protector]]. Although this post was elective, not hereditary, it was to be held for life. It also required the calling of triennial [[Parliament]]s, with each sitting for at least five months.
In January 1655, Cromwell dissolved the [[first Protectorate Parliament]], ushering in a period of [[Military dictatorship|military rule]] by the [[Rule of the Major-Generals|Major Generals]].
The ''Instrument of Government'' was replaced in May 1657 by England's second, and last, codified [[constitution]], the [[Humble Petition and Advice]]. However Oliver Cromwell died the next year and his nominated successor as Lord Protector, his son [[Richard Cromwell|Richard]], proved unable to govern effectively as various political parties strove to gain power.
[[The Protectorate]] came to an end in May 1659 when the Grandees recalled the Rump Parliament, which authorised a [[Committee of Safety (England)|Committee of Safety]] to replace Richard's [[Council of State (England)|Council of State]]. This ushered in a period of unstable government, which did not come to an end until February 1660 when General [[George Monck]], the English military governor of Scotland, marched to London at the head of his troops, and oversaw the [[Restoration (England)|restoration of the monarchy]] under Charles II.
==Life during the Interregnum== After the Parliamentarian victory in the Civil War, the [[Puritan]] views of the majority of Parliament and its supporters began to be imposed on the rest of the country. The Puritans advocated an austere lifestyle and restricted what they saw as the excesses of the previous regime. Most prominently, holidays such as Christmas and Easter were suppressed.{{sfn|Durston|1985}} Pastimes such as the theatre and gambling were also banned. However, some forms of art that were thought to be "virtuous", such as opera, were encouraged. These changes are often credited to [[Oliver Cromwell]], though they were introduced by the Commonwealth Parliament; and Cromwell, when he came to power, was a liberalising influence.<ref>''Cromwell, Our Chief of Men'' by [[Lady Antonia Fraser]], {{ISBN|0-7538-1331-9}}.</ref>
==Jews in England== {{Main|Resettlement of the Jews in England}}
[[Rabbi]] [[Menasseh Ben Israel]] met Oliver Cromwell in 1655 in order to discuss the admission of Jews into England.<ref>[http://www.olivercromwell.org/jews.htm "Cromwell and the Jews"], The Oliver Cromwell Association.</ref> Cromwell did not agree to all the rights that Ben Israel requested, but the opening of Jewish [[synagogues]] and [[burial ground]]s was tolerated under Cromwell's Protectorate. The Jewish faith was still not practised openly in England, since Cromwell's move had been controversial and many in England were still hostile toward Jews. Life for [[Jews in England]] improved in that they could no longer be [[prosecute]]d if caught worshipping, yet [[discrimination]] continued.
== Radicals vs conservatives == Parliament had, to a large degree, encouraged the radical political groups which emerged when the usual social controls broke down during the [[English Civil War]]. It had also unwittingly established a new political force when it set up the [[New Model Army]]. Not surprisingly, all these groups had their own hopes for the new Commonwealth.
=== Levellers === Led by [[John Lilburne]], [[Levellers]] drew their main support from London and the Army. In the [[Agreement of the People]], 1649, they asked for a more representative and accountable parliament, to meet every two years; a reform of law so it would be available to and fair to all; and religious toleration. They wanted a more [[democracy|democratic]] society, although their proposed franchise did not extend to women or to the lowest orders of society.
Levellers saw the Rump as little better than the monarchy it had replaced, and they showed their displeasure in demonstrations, pamphlets and mutinies. While their numbers did not pose a serious threat to the government, they scared the Rump into action and a [[Treasons Act 1649|Treasons Act]] was passed against them in 1649.
=== Diggers === Led by [[Gerrard Winstanley]], [[Diggers]] wanted an even more equal society than the Levellers. They advocated a lifestyle that bore many similarities to later understandings of [[communism]] and [[anarchism]], with communal ownership of land, and absolute equality for males and females in law and education. They existed in only very small numbers and faced a very strong opposition, even from the Levellers.
=== Religious sects === {{see also|Religion during the Interregnum}}
The breakdown of religious uniformity and incomplete [[Presbyterian]] Settlement of 1646 enabled independent churches to flourish. The main sects (''see also [[English Dissenters]]'') were [[Baptists]], who advocated adult re[[baptism]]; [[Ranters]], who claimed that sin did not exist for the "chosen ones"; and [[Fifth Monarchy Men]], who opposed all "earthly" governments, believing they must prepare for God's kingdom on earth by establishing a "government of saints".
Despite greater toleration, extreme sects were opposed by the upper classes as they were seen as a threat to social order and property rights. [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholics]] were also excluded from the toleration applied to the other groups.
=== Conservatives === Conservatives were still dominant in both [[central government]] and [[local government]]. In the former, the Rump was anxious not to offend the traditional ruling class whose support it needed for survival, so it opposed radical ideas. In the latter, that ruling class dominated through the influence of traditional regional gentry.
==Historical analysis== The Interregnum was a relatively short but important period in the history of the British Isles. It saw a number of political experiments without any stable form of government emerging, largely due to the wide diversity in religious and political groups that had been allowed to flourish after the regicide of Charles I.
The [[Puritan]] movement had evolved as a rejection of both real and perceived "Catholicisation" of the [[Church of England]]. When the Church of England was quickly [[Established church#Disestablishment|disestablished]] by the Commonwealth Government, the question of what church to establish became a hotly debated subject. In the end, it was impossible to make all the political factions happy. During the Interregnum, Oliver Cromwell lost much of the support he had gained during the Civil War. [[Edward Sexby]], previously a supporter of Cromwell's, felt disenfranchised by Cromwell's failure to abolish the [[aristocracy]]. In 1657, [[Silius Titus]] called for Cromwell's assassination in a co-authored pamphlet ''[[Killing No Murder]]'' under the pseudonym of William Allen. Sexby was captured when he returned to England and attempted to carry out the assassination described in Colonel Titus' book. Cromwell coerced Sexby into confessing authorship of the pamphlet and then imprisoned him in the [[Tower of London]], where Sexby was driven to insanity, dying there less than a year later.
High taxes required by the large [[standing army]], kept due to the constant threats of Scottish and Irish rebellion, added to public resentment of Cromwell.
